chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect food allergy?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Suspect a diagnosis of immediate IgE-mediated food allergy if there are typical clinical features:
    • Classical symptoms which develop within seconds or minutes to 1–2 hours after ingestion of a specific trigger food, and typically resolve before 12 hours:
      • Systemic — respiratory distress, severe wheezing, hypotension, tachycardia or bradycardia, drowsiness, confusion, collapse and loss of consciousness, which suggests life-threatening anaphylaxis. See the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information on emergency management.
      • Skin — urticaria, angio-oedema (most commonly of the lips, face, and around the eyes), erythema, generalized itching, and flushing. See the CKS topic on Urticaria for more information.
      • Respiratory — persistent cough, hoarseness, wheeze, breathlessness, stridor; nasal discharge, congestion, itching, and sneezing. See the CKS topics on Asthma and Allergic rhinitis for more information.
      • Gastrointestinal — nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain.
    • Symptoms suggesting a diagnosis of oral allergy syndrome (pollen-food syndrome) or latex-fruit syndrome:
      • Oral allergy syndrome — typically mild, transient localized urticaria and associated tingling, itching, and swelling of the lips, tongue, and throat, often with co-morbid allergic rhinitis symptoms, after ingestion of fresh fruit or vegetables. Symptoms tend to be worse when the pollen count is high. See the CKS topic on Allergic rhinitis for more information.
      • Latex-fruit syndrome — people with known latex allergy may present with a variety of symptoms including urticaria, angio-oedema, oral symptoms, or anaphylaxis following ingestion of certain fruits and nuts.
      • Note: be aware that a diagnosis of primary nut allergy and oral allergy syndrome may co-exist.
  • Consider a diagnosis of food allergy in people who have unexplained persistent symptoms of:
    • Atopic eczema — see the CKS topic on Eczema - atopic for more information.
    • Faltering growth — see the CKS topic on Faltering growth for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect food allergy are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Food allergy in under 19s: assessment and diagnosis [NICE, 2018], the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (RCPCH) publication Allergy Care Pathways for Children. Food allergy [RCPCH, 2011], the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) Guideline for the diagnosis and management of peanut and tree nut allergy [Stiefel, 2017], the International Collaboration in Asthma, Allergy and Immunology consensus document ICON: Food allergy [Burks, 2012], the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of food allergy in the United States [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in review articles on food allergy [Longo, 2013; Steele, 2014; Turnbull, 2015; Meyer, 2018], oral allergy syndrome [Price, 2015], and latex-fruit syndrome [Blanco, 2003].

When to suspect food allergy

  • The NICE clinical guideline based its list of clinical symptoms of food allergy on the guideline development group's expertise and clinical experience [NICE, 2018]. 
  • The information on when to suspect oral allergy syndrome and latex-fruit syndrome is based on the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], the BSACI guideline [Stiefel, 2017], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in review articles [Blanco, 2003; Price, 2015; Turnbull, 2015].
    • The information that primary nut allergy and oral allergy syndrome can co-exist is based on the BSACI guideline.

When to consider food allergy

  • The recommendations on when to consider a diagnosis of food allergy are based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in a review article [Meyer, 2018].
